10.45.text:
>>Malcolm Grant: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome
everybody here in the hall of the Royal College

16.85.text:
of Obstetricians and Gynaecology in London
to this, our AGM for NHS England. It is my

25.22.text:
great pleasure as the Chairman of NHS England
to introduce this evening’s proceedings.

30.88.text:
Before I do, what I would like to do is to
introduce individually the members of the

36.63.text:
Board of NHS England. These are the people
who take the decisions and who provide the

41.33.text:
leadership for the organisation. With us tonight
– and I am going to ask each of them please

47.16.text:
to stand as I mention their names – first,
the Deputy Chairman of the Board, David Roberts.

54.90.text:
Thank you, David. David is also the Chairman
of Nationwide Building Society. He brings

59.25.text:
a great deal of expertise to the deliberations
of the Board. Joanne Shaw, who has now succeeded

66.26.text:
David as chairing our Audit and Risk Assurance
Committee, unfortunately is not able to be

70.40.text:
with us this evening, and she has just recently
joined the Board. Lord Victor Adebowale is

76.69.text:
also the Chief Executive of Turning Point,
and a member of the House of Lords. He brings

81.69.text:
valuable areas to our deliberations, particularly
relating to marginalised communities and to

87.96.text:
mental ill health. Beside him is Sir John
Burn, a globally renowned clinical geneticist

94.49.text:
and clinical scientist, innovator and inventor.
Dame Moira Gibb, who is the Chair of Skills

102.21.text:
for Care, and also formerly the Chief Executive
of Camden London Borough Council. Beside her,

108.75.text:
Wendy Becker. Wendy previously has been the
Chief Marketing Officer globally for Vodafone,

117.21.text:
Chief Executive of Jack Wills and the Deputy
Chair of Cancer Research UK. I am looking

124.18.text:
for any other non-executive directors. I see
Noel Gordon. Noel spent 26 years with Accenture

131.19.text:
in a consultancy role. He has recently also
taken on the Chairmanship of NHS Digital,

137.77.text:
formerly known as the Health and Social Care
Information Centre, and we are delighted to

142.30.text:
have the joining-up that that brings to our
arrangements. Michelle Mitchell, who is the

148.66.text:
Chief Executive of Multiple Sclerosis, is
an important recent member of the non-executive

157.02.text:
On the executive side, we have a team – as
I go along the front row – with Matthew

168.93.text:
Swindells, who is the National Director for
Operations and Information; he joined us in

176.49.text:
May this year. As I come along here, Ian Dodge,
who is our Commissioning Strategy National

183.05.text:
Director. Next to him, Karen Wheeler, who
is our Director for Transformation and Corporate

190.12.text:
Operations; I love ‘Transformation’ and
Corporate Operations. Paul Baumann, our Finance

195.24.text:
Director, is unfortunately not able to be
with us this evening. Jane Cummings, our Chief

199.58.text:
Nursing Officer, is here, as is Sir Bruce
Keogh, our National Medical Director, and

207.60.text:
of course our Chief Executive, Simon Stevens.
Simon will be addressing us in the course

215.06.text:
During the course of the past year, two non-executive
directors have stood down from the Board.

219.74.text:
The first was Ciarán Devane, upon the expiry
of his term, but also on taking on the Chief

225.82.text:
Executiveship of the British Council. The
second was Margaret Casely-Hayford, who has

230.95.text:
taken on the Chairmanship of Action Aid. We
also lost Dame Barbara Hakin after 41 years

237.49.text:
working in the NHS, who has taken retirement,
and Tim Kelsey, who has gone to Australia

243.23.text:
first of all to head up Telstra Health, and
then subsequently to take on a leading government

248.35.text:
position in Australia. On behalf of the Board,
I would like to thank all of those individuals

253.50.text:
for their hard work and contribution to the
health of NHS England.

260.16.text:
Over the course of the year since we last
gathered for an AGM, there has been a dramatic

266.64.text:
change in the political environment in which
we are operating. The campaign around the

273.75.text:
referendum on 23rd June had as one of its
key components the NHS. The slogan on the

282.03.text:
battle bus was, ‘We send the EU £350 million
a week. Let’s fund our NHS instead.’

292.30.text:
It was not surprising that the NHS should have
played such a key role, given the level of

296.57.text:
trust that it holds in the estimation of the
British public, but the outcome of the referendum

303.73.text:
has had a darkening of a political mood and
some chill winds growing across the landscape,

310.38.text:
not only of the nation as a whole but also
of the NHS. It has created in many parts of

316.94.text:
the country a growing polarisation. The incidence
of hate crimes has been rising, and the experience

323.67.text:
of those working in the NHS has not been immune
to that subtle but quite worrying change in

330.32.text:
public opinion. It has been, of course, reflected
elsewhere. This is not simply a UK phenomenon;

336.71.text:
we see similar trends emerging in France and
in the US. The uncertainty has caused a dramatic

345.19.text:
change in the value of the pound, but as we
know, financial markets do not like uncertainty

351.98.text:
and will discount for it. However, financial
markets are not in themselves supergods; financial

357.47.text:
markets are agglomerations of individuals’
preferences. The uncertainties that affect

362.63.text:
financial markets affect all of those who
work also for the National Health Service.

369.52.text:
What is the challenge for us within the NHS?
I think the first is to provide assurance

376.46.text:
for the 53,000 EU nationals who work for the
NHS of our continued reliance, dependence

384.93.text:
and affection for the contribution that they
make to the health of our organisation and

390.34.text:
to the health of our citizens. We have to
appreciate that, for them and for many tens

397.01.text:
of thousands of international employees who
are non-EU, there is a strong relationship

404.20.text:
between their earnings in this country and
the remittances which they send abroad to

408.84.text:
families, the value of which has just dropped
by 15% in the value of sterling.

415.98.text:
Our response, I would suggest, is along the
three lines that follow. First, it is essential

421.49.text:
that we in NHS England, as an independent
arm’s-length body, work in close partnership

427.23.text:
with the government to provide assurance across
our staff of the future of the NHS and their

433.86.text:
position in it, and to provide a counter to
the uncertainty that presently prevails. Secondly,

441.76.text:
to provide stability over the coming years
at a time of great change; as we will learn

448.09.text:
this afternoon as we look at the Five Year
Forward View and the work of the STPs, change

454.64.text:
must occur, and yet stability must prevail,
and the stability is reinforced by having

460.63.text:
allocated our funding for the next five years,
by having a mandate that runs for five years,

465.19.text:
and a clear vision of the future as an organisation.
Then I think finally, to work in close partnership

472.44.text:
with the government in supporting some areas
of important economic development in the United

479.28.text:
Kingdom, most importantly the life sciences.
We have a unique agglomeration of pharmaceutical

486.02.text:
and medical devices, and other investment
in the UK. We have the unique position of

490.34.text:
a major single-payer health service with the
capacity to work closely on medical experimentation

496.87.text:
and innovation. We have an opportunity to
review the current quite restrictive EU regulation

503.28.text:
of medical experimentation and clinical trials,
and an opportunity to work to advance that

509.25.text:
industry in conjunction with advancing the
cause of patients and clinicians within the

514.57.text:
NHS. The Accelerated Access Review, which
was announced yesterday, is a major step forward

520.64.text: in allowing us to realise that.

523.09.text:
Our message this evening must be one not of
grudging acceptance of the outcome of Brexit,

530.58.text:
but of grasping the opportunities that it
gives us for the NHS and to take forward the

535.38.text:
interests of our staff and our patients at
the same time.

539.10.text:
It gives me enormous pleasure now to introduce
our moderator for this evening, Martha Kearney.

552.34.text:
>>Martha Kearney: Thank you very much indeed,
Sir Malcolm. I would just like to repeat his

555.93.text:
welcome to you all here for the Annual General
Meeting of the NHS in England. This is a chance

561.75.text:
to hear about the past two years of the Five
Year Forward View, about some of the new initiatives

568.84.text:
that the Health Service is working on and
how it plans to address the challenges of

573.93.text:
today and of tomorrow. It is also a chance
for all of you to ask questions. We do not

580.67.text:
have a huge amount of time, so I am saying
‘questions’ rather than speeches. Do keep

585.15.text:
it brief; I will warn you, I will be brutal.
If you do not have a chance to ask your question

589.43.text:
now, by all means you can write on the board
at the back of the room, or also on the feedback

594.00.text:
form that you should all have on your chairs.
To begin with, I would like to invite the

599.05.text:
Chief Executive of NHS England, Simon Stevens,
up here to say a few words of introduction

605.07.text:
and to discuss also NHS England’s annual
report and accounts.

617.56.text:
>>Simon Stevens: Thanks very much, Martha,
and good evening or good afternoon everybody.

621.34.text:
Thank you for joining us at this AGM. I really
have two responsibilities. One is a brief

628.59.text:
look back at the year 2015/2016, last year,
and then an even briefer look forward to the

636.64.text:
year we are in and the journey that the NHS
is now embarked on. That is really just going

641.83.text:
to tee up what are going to be two panels,
one of which will comprise people who genuinely

647.25.text:
know what they are talking about and are leading
fantastic change in our mental health services,

651.59.text:
our cancer services, our urgent and emergency
care services and learning disability. The

657.05.text:
second will be a panel of some of our most
engaged local leaders trying to shape their

663.76.text:
care systems across the country, that Matthew
Swindells will be helping to facilitate.

671.60.text:
Looking back at last year, 2015/2016, the
honest assessment has to be that it was an

678.99.text:
incredibly challenging year for the National
Health Service. It was challenging for our

685.15.text:
front‑line staff, for nurses, GPs, A&E doctors,
therapists and administrative staff. It was

692.61.text:
a year in which pressures continued to build,
and that showed up as pressures on the headline

699.93.text:
goals around A&E four-hour attendance and
waiting times for routine surgeries. However,

707.91.text:
without in any way detracting from that reality,
I think it is vitally important that we recall

713.15.text:
that it is still the case that people in England
are getting some of the fastest access to

719.95.text:
A&E services and planned surgery of any industrialised
country in the world, for the whole country.

725.16.text:
That is the social contract that the National
Health Service offers. More than nine in ten

729.78.text:
people last year were seen and treated in
A&Es within four hours; more than nine in

736.40.text:
ten people got their planned surgery within
18 weeks, compared with the position a decade

743.75.text:
earlier when people were waiting 18 months.
So, real pressures on front‑line staff as

750.71.text:
a result of a growing and ageing population
and the resource constraints, but nevertheless

755.22.text:
an overall performance that I think we can
be proud of, not least when we think about

759.01.text:
the other parts of what the Health Service
does that are not represented in those headline

766.62.text:
Those operational pressures were correspondingly
represented by financial pressures, and in

774.28.text:
the absence of Paul Baumann, our Chief Financial
Officer, it simply falls to me to report to

780.78.text:
you that NHS England last year met each of
our financial obligations to Parliament. For

787.36.text:
those of you interested in reviewing them
in detail, I refer you to page 184 of our

792.87.text:
annual report which is available on the NHS
England website. Suffice it to say that personally,

798.45.text:
as the accounting officer to Parliament for
the £101 billion of public money that NHS

804.30.text:
England was invested with last year, we met
each of those responsibilities; we managed

808.56.text:
to our budget, and in fact we produced a planned
underspend of £599 million to contribute

816.29.text:
to wider funding pressures in hospitals and
in other parts of the National Health Service.

823.72.text:
What we also did last year, I think very importantly,
was chart strategic directions for some of

830.69.text:
the big killers, disablers and health conditions
in this country, and detailed blueprints as

836.22.text:
to how we are going to improve them over the
next five years. We did this not by retreating

842.72.text:
into a darkened room and a group of NHS folks
coming up with what they felt was the answer,

848.03.text:
but instead for the first time by, in the
jargon, ‘co‑producing’ this with the

853.37.text:
patients’ groups, the charities, the clinicians
who lead our mental health services, our cancer

860.56.text:
services, learning disability services and
maternity services. As a result, we now have

865.18.text:
very clear marching orders as to what it is
we have to do across the country to raise

870.87.text: our game on those key national priorities.

877.00.text:
This time last year at our Annual General
Meeting, I took the unusual step of publicly

881.77.text:
commenting on the state of the negotiations
between ourselves and the government on the

888.06.text:
Spending Review, the five-year Spending Review,
which was then in its final few weeks of negotiation.

895.25.text:
I described five tests, five criteria, that
we would use to judge whether or not the funding

902.76.text:
available to us matched the expectations set
out in the NHS Five Year Forward View. As

911.74.text:
the year has played out, we successfully got
the front-loaded funding settlement for 2016/2017,

920.96.text:
broadly speaking, that we were asking for;
and as I have explained to the Public Accounts

926.38.text:
Committee and to the Health Selection Committee,
in five years’ time, in year five of the

930.11.text:
Spending Review, we were broadly in the zone
that we talked about, albeit at the lower

934.78.text:
end of the range.
However, terms and conditions apply, and one

938.86.text:
of those was that the country would need to
continue to see well-funded social care services,

946.14.text:
able to respond to increasing need for publicly
funded care homes and home support. We would

954.45.text:
need to see continued progress on prevention,
and we would need funding for capital investment

961.77.text:
and infrastructure, and all of those we have
written on something called the Recap Briefing,

968.12.text:
setting out very clearly the need for those
preconditions to be in place. I think it is

973.46.text:
fair to say, and we have reported to Parliament,
that we do not believe all of those are yet

978.11.text:
in place. In terms of the funding settlement
that we received – again, this is not a

982.33.text:
new statement, but for the purposes of the
AGM I think it is important to recap – we

988.36.text:
did not get the funding that we requested
for years two, three and four of the five-year

993.78.text:
Spending Review, namely 2017/2018, 2018/2019
and 2019/2020, with the consequence that we

1000.25.text:
have a bigger hill to climb when we think
about the kinds of pressures that will be

1004.78.text: facing the NHS over the next three years.

1009.24.text:
Looking forward, then, to the year we are
in and beyond, what are the things that we

1014.52.text:
at NHS England have to get right? First of
all, we need to continue to work very closely

1023.09.text:
with our national partners – with NHS Improvement,
with the Care Quality Commission, with the

1028.09.text:
other parts of the national architecture of
the NHS – to ensure that there is a joined-up

1034.99.text:
and coherent approach to the leadership of
the task in front of the NHS as a whole, rather

1041.50.text:
than the fragmented and diffuse set of responsibilities
that, done badly, could be the net effect

1048.09.text:
of the national architecture that we have
all inherited. I think our joint working with

1054.36.text:
NHS Improvement in particular has moved forward
in leaps and bounds over the course of the

1059.16.text:
last year, and we need to continue to build
on that.

1063.18.text:
Secondly, we need to ensure that we effectively
fulfil our unique legal responsibilities as

1069.39.text:
stewards of the commissioning system, ensuring
that local clinical commissioning groups and

1075.34.text:
our national specialised commissioning responsibilities
are discharged effectively. I am pleased to

1080.24.text:
say that last year we made further progress
in our specialised commissioning responsibilities,

1087.23.text:
ensuring that the core budget was balanced,
and we made important improvements in the

1091.63.text:
way in which we are procuring cancer medicines
and other services across the country.

1099.40.text:
Thirdly, we need to make tangible gains on
the agenda we have set ourselves on mental

1104.90.text:
health services, on cancer, on support in
particular for GPs and primary care, and for

1112.36.text:
the broader redesign of urgent and emergency
care, and that is what our two panels are

1116.41.text:
going to help talk about. I particularly want
to pay attention to and draw your attention

1123.90.text:
to our work to try and improve the resilience
of GP services across this country. I think

1130.63.text:
we are pleased that, whereas in every year
prior to the existence of NHS England, for

1138.56.text:
almost a decade, the share of investment going
into GP services was going down, in every

1145.17.text:
year since the creation of NHS England we
have seen real increases in funding for GPs,

1150.54.text:
and last year that was at two times the rate
of the overall funding increase. Together

1155.79.text:
with our partners in the Royal College of
General Practitioners, front‑line GPs and

1159.86.text:
the General Practitioners Committee, we now
have a very clear game plan for investment

1165.37.text:
in general practice, another £2.4 billion
over the next five years, for improvement

1171.55.text:
in the staffing available: not just GPs, but
also pharmacists, mental health therapists

1178.91.text:
and other staff in general practice; investment
in GP premises to deal with some of the infrastructure

1183.96.text:
issues that are there; and a broad programme
to redesign the way GP services link with

1191.03.text:
hospital outpatients, community service and
social care, to deal with some of the frustration

1196.68.text:
on the part of both patients and the general
practitioners.

1201.51.text:
We have to get the alignment with the other
national leadership bodies, we have our stewardship

1205.89.text:
responsibilities for the commissioning system,
we have to make tangible gains over the next

1210.31.text:
year on our national priorities, and we have
to support, above all, the work of local leaders

1218.57.text:
through, call it the sustainability and transformation
plans; it does not really matter what you

1223.04.text:
call it: the process which is now underway
in every part of the country to actually ensure

1227.38.text:
that the NHS and our partners in local government
and the third sector are coming together to

1233.45.text:
chart a direction, an agreed direction, to
use the funding available to produce local

1238.51.text:
improvement. That is a tremendously complex
undertaking. It is in some ways counter-cultural

1244.76.text:
to the incentives that have been in the National
Health Service for at least two decades, which

1249.43.text:
each organisation out, sharp-elbowed, doing
its own thing. Now, there is a realisation

1255.67.text:
that people actually have to behave in ways
that are more than the sum of their parts

1260.31.text:
if we are going to see the sorts of improvements
we want on health and care quality, and the

1265.13.text: sustainability of how we use our resources.

1269.30.text:
This is clearly a highly complex and very
pressurised time in the 68-year history of

1275.46.text:
the National Health Service. We have certain
things going for us, namely the fact that,

1281.07.text:
broadly speaking, there is an agreed direction
about what health and care quality and the

1285.85.text:
efficiency agenda needs to look like. However,
we know that time is not on our side, and

1291.95.text:
actually what the people of this country want
are practical improvements in ways that can

1299.03.text:
be noticed and have beneficial impact, and
that is what our staff are looking for as

1303.77.text:
well. There is often a sensation that they
are succeeding despite the system not because

1307.92.text:
of it, and so it is all of our responsibilities
to do what we can to enable that local change

1314.06.text:
process to occur in every part of the country.
Thank you again for being here this afternoon.

1320.78.text:
I think we will now get straight into the
first panel, talking about what we are doing

1325.73.text:
on mental health, cancer and some of the other
national priorities.
